title: Quiz 1: Normal Labour Fundamentals
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Fundamental concepts of normal labour including definition, onset, and the three Ps

questions.question: What is the most accurate definition of labour?

options.text: The period from conception to birth
The process by which the fetus, placenta, and membranes are expelled from the uterus
The delivery of the baby only

questions.explanation: Labour is defined as the complete process by which the fetus, placenta, and membranes are expelled from the uterus through the birth canal.
questions.hint: Think about what is expelled during the entire birthing process, not just the baby.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the 'Three Ps' of labour?
questions.explanation: The Three Ps of labour are: Power (uterine contractions), Passageway (pelvis and birth canal), and Passenger (fetus). These three factors must be favorable for normal labour to progress.
questions.hint: Each P represents a critical element that must work together for successful delivery.

questions.question: Normal labour begins with regular, painful uterine contractions that result in cervical effacement and dilatation.
questions.explanation: True. The onset of labour is characterized by regular, painful uterine contractions that cause progressive cervical effacement (thinning) and dilatation (opening).
questions.hint: Consider what makes contractions different in true labour versus false labour.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical signs of true labour? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Regular contractions that increase in frequency and intensity
Contractions that are relieved by walking
Irregular contractions that decrease with activity

questions.explanation: True labour signs include regular contractions that increase in frequency and intensity, bloody show, and progressive cervical dilatation. False labour contractions are irregular and often relieved by walking.
questions.hint: Focus on signs that indicate progressive changes in the cervix and contractions.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ refers to the uterine contractions, which provide the force needed to expel the fetus.
questions.explanation: Power refers to the uterine contractions that provide the force necessary to expel the fetus through the birth canal. Adequate power is essential for normal labour progress.
questions.hint: This is the first 'P' in the Three Ps of labour.

questions.question: Match each 'P' of labour with its correct description:
questions.explanation: Power = uterine contractions, Passageway = pelvis and birth canal, Passenger = fetus and placenta. All three must be favorable for normal labour.
questions.hint: Think about what each 'P' represents physically in the labour process.

questions.question: A primigravida woman presents with regular contractions every 5 minutes lasting 45 seconds. Her cervix is 3 cm dilated and 80% effaced. What stage of labour is she in?
questions.explanation: The latent phase of the first stage is characterized by cervical dilatation from 0 to 3-4 cm. This woman is 3 cm dilated with regular contractions, placing her in the latent phase.
questions.hint: The latent phase typically involves dilatation up to 3-4 cm.

questions.question: Which fetal presentation is most common and considered optimal for vaginal delivery?
questions.explanation: Cephalic presentation (head first) is the most common fetal presentation, occurring in approximately 95-97% of deliveries. It is the optimal presentation for vaginal delivery.
questions.hint: This presentation involves the baby's head coming first through the birth canal.

questions.question: The passenger (fetus) includes only the baby and not the placenta or membranes.
questions.explanation: False. The passenger includes the fetus, placenta, and membranes. All of these must be expelled during the labour process.
questions.hint: Consider everything that needs to be expelled from the uterus during delivery.

questions.question: What term describes the thinning and shortening of the cervix during labour?
questions.explanation: Effacement refers to the thinning and shortening of the cervix during labour. It is measured in percentages from 0% (long, thick cervix) to 100% (fully thinned).
questions.hint: This process allows the cervix to open more easily for delivery.
